awd_titl_txt: CAREER: An integrated probabilistic approach to discrete and continuous extremal problems via information theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematics  abounds  with extremal  problems  problems  where  the  goal  is  to  minimize some  functional  applied  to  a  class  of  objects  under  some constraint,  identify  the  extremal  objects,  and  investigate  the stability  of  extrema.  Relevant  examples  range  from  some  in the  continuous  world  (isoperimetric  phenomena  in  convex geometry,  functional  analytic  inequalities),  to  some  in  the
discrete  world  (structural  phenomena  in  additive  combinatorics), and  some  in  both  (maximum  entropy  problems  in  statistics, limit  theorems  in  probability).  A  natural  language  for  all  of these  problem  classes  is  probability,  and,  although  not obvious,  information  theory.  The  project  will  develop  new formulations  of  extremal  problems  from  each  of  these  fields in  terms  of  information-theoretic  inequalities,  and  then  use  a variety  of  tools  from  analysis,  probability,  convex  geometry, combinatorics,  and  information  theory,  to  make  progress  on them.  The  unifying  nature  of  the  perspective  adopted  will bridge  discrete  and  continuous  problems  using  a  common  set  of tools,  and  enable  significant  cross-fertilization.  Furthermore, some  of  the  information-theoretic  inequalities  developed, combined  with  statistical  decision  theory,  will  be  applied  to novel  statistical  challenges  involving  multiple  players  that arise  in  engineering,  economics,  and  biology  (specifically, theoretical  foundations  for  the  problems  of  data  pricing  and distributed  inference).    The  project  will  use information-theoretic  thinking  to  make  advances  on  challenging mathematical  problems  from  the  three  seemingly  disparate  fields of  convex  geometry,  arithmetic  combinatorics,  and  probability.

Apart  from  the  intrinsic  significance  of  these  areas  within mathematics,  they  have  much  practical  significance - convex geometry  finds  applications  in  medical  tomography,  arithmetic combinatorics  in  computer  science,  and  probability  is ubiquitous  as  the  foundation  of  statistical  inference.  The interpretability  and  unifying  nature  of  the  proposed  research, and  the  diversity  of  tools  it  uses,  create  wonderful  opportunities   for  student  motivation.  Newly  developed  courses  and  a resource  website  on  information  theoretic  approaches  to extremal  problems  will  exploit  these  opportunities.  The investigator  will  disseminate  key  findings  through  survey articles,  organize  an  interdisciplinary  workshop,  and communicate  the  excitement  of  research  through  non-academic public  lectures  to  attract  promising  students  to  the mathematical  sciences.  The  applied  component  of  the  research would  also  have  broad  impact,  by  contributing  to  how  data collectors  and  vendors  come  up  with  pricing  mechanisms  (e.g., for  pricing  of  advertisements  by  search  engines),  and  by improving  the  way  networks  of  sensors  collect  and  use  data for  various  applications  (e.g.,  for  disaster  recovery coordination  or  smart  kindergartens).

por.por_cntn:
Broadly speaking, the aim of this project is to use ideas from information theory, which originated as a field of electrical engineering and underlies modern communication, to study and illuminate optimization problems in several areas of mathematics, each of which also have practical ramifications in the real world. The optimization problems studied come from information theory itself (which describes the fundamental limits of communications across channels and networks), convex geometry (ideas from which explain the fact that soap bubbles are spherical), additive combinatorics (which studies mathematical structures that have significant applications to computer science algorithms), and probability theory (which is the foundation of statistics and data science). 

Results from the project have been disseminated through 43 peer-reviewed publications, invited talks at 35 conferences and at over 50 universities, and multiple invited lecture series at institutions in the US, Europe, and Asia.

The project developed new formulations of optimization problems from each of these fields in terms of so-called "information-theoretic inequalities", and then used a variety of tools from different areas of mathematics to make significant advances. Some of the major themes and outcomes are briefly described below.

1)  The "geometrization of probability" program: Convex geometry studies notions like volume and surface area for certain nice sets of points in the plane, 3-dimensional space, and higher-dimensional spaces that have great importance in real-world applications. V. Milman proposed a program about two decades ago to embed convex geometry in a more general geometric or analytic setting. While one approach to this program (where the integral of a function plays the role of the volume) had been developed earlier, this project played a key role in developing a second approach (via probability, where entropy plays the role of volume). Crucially this project introduced and developed the notion of "concentration of information" for convex measures, which has now become a standard and very useful tool in this and allied areas.

2)  Entropic limit theorems: Limit theorems in probability explain why certain particular distributions such as the "bell curve" or normal distribution, and the Poisson distribution are good models for many applications, and why they are ubiquitous in data analysis. A deeper understanding of these phenomena can be obtained using entropy. One project outcome was such a deeper understanding for a large class of limit theorems involving compound Poisson distributions.

3)  The convexifying effect of Minkowski summation: Minkowski summation is a way to "add" sets of points in the plane, or more general higher-dimensional spaces. It has long been known that adding a large number of arbitrary sets together results in a set that is nice in the sense of being approximately convex. This fact has many implications, including for market equilibria in economics. The project resulted in a significantly deeper understanding of this phenomenon.

4)  Other directions: The project also supported work in other directions, including additive combinatorics, harmonic analysis, distributed statistical inference, stochastic process theory, and information and communication theory.

In addition to the intellectual merit in the project outcomes, the unifying perspective enabled significant cross-fertilization, and is likely to remain influential in future work in these areas.

The broader impact of the project has been significant, and is outlined below.

1)  Impact on Applications: The project outputs have become useful tools, providing key ingredients for a wide variety of engineering and computer science applications including the degrees of freedom of interference channels, wiretap networks, multilevel diversity coding, control and sensor network theory, communication complexity, distributed function computation, and data pricing. Some project outputs also provided rigorous mathematical justification for results in statistical physics that physicists understand based on intuition. 

2)  Impact on Human Resources: The project supported several graduate students, the summer research experiences of two undergraduates, and also benefited a postdoctoral researcher. Of the persons who benefited from the project, two joined the skilled U.S. workforce in industry and three in academics. The PI also mentored some high school students who proceeded to pursue mathematics in college.

3)  Educational Impact: The PI developed and delivered four new courses, wrote three substantial survey papers that have become widely used resources for graduate students entering the research areas of this project, did some outreach to popularize mathematics research to high school and college students, and co-organized half a dozen workshops (including one directly supported by the project). The workshops provided opportunities for researchers in different fields connected by this project to interact, and also gave exposure to a number of graduate students and young researchers.
